conclusion: Problem involves shadows cast by four objects on a wooden surface.
Objects are an apple, a piece of paper, and two others labeled C and D.
Shadows are labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
Question asks how shadows change when light source moves upward.
Need to consider both position and size of shadows.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a light source.
Size and position of shadow depend on light source and object position.
Current setup involves a wooden surface and light source above it.
Light source moving upward affects length and position of shadows.
Consider each object one by one starting with the apple.
Apple is a round object casting shadow labeled A.
Apple's shadow should become smaller and move closer when light source moves upward.
Piece of paper is a flat object casting shadow labeled B.
Paper's shadow should become smaller and move closer when light source moves upward.
Object C is casting shadow labeled C.
Object C's shadow should become smaller and move closer when light source moves upward.
Object D is casting shadow labeled D.
Object D's shadow should become smaller and move closer when light source moves upward.
Image shows apple, paper, chicken leg, and transparent object.
Four objects above slabs casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
